Read template and data files into a list structure

Source: R/read_files.R
read_files.Rd

Read metadata templates, data files, and function arguments into an R list structure as an alternative input to EMLassemblyline functions (i.e. rather than supplying the files themselves).

This function enables programatic interfacing of upstream sources with EMLassemblyline (e.g. a metabase or database). See below for valid list structure.

read_files(
      path,
      data.path = path,
      data.table = NULL,
      other.entity = NULL,
      sep = NULL
    )

Arguments

path

(character) Path to metadata templates.
data.path

(character) Path to data tables and other entities.
data.table

(character) Data table name(s). If more than one, then supply as a vector of character strings (e.g. data.table = c("concentrations.csv", "characteristics.csv")).
other.entity

(character) Name(s) of other.entity(s) in this dataset. Use other.entity for all non-data.table files. other.entity(s) should be stored at data.path.
sep

(character) Delimiter of data.table. Use this argument if read_files() fails to automatically identify data.table field delimiters.

Value

(named list) Named list with this internal structure.:

  • template Metadata template files

    • abstract.txt Abstract template

      • content EML::TextType containing abstract, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • additional_info.txt Additional information template

      • content EML::TextType containing additional info, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • attributes_name.txt Attributes template where "name" is name of data.table described by the attributes. Don't include if missing.

      • content Data frame of attributes template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • bounding_boxes.txt Bounding boxes template

      • content Data frame of bounding boxes template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • catvars_name.txt Categorical variables template where name is name of data.table described by the catvars. Don't include if missing.

      • content Data frame of categorical variables template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • custom_units.txt Custom units template

      • content Data frame of custom units template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • geographic_coverage.txt Geographic coverage template

      • content Data frame of geographic coverage template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • intellectual_rights.txt Intellectual rights template

      • content EML::TextType containing intellectual rights, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • keywords.txt Keywords template

      • content Data frame of keywords template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • methods.txt Methods template

      • content EML::Methods containing methods, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • personnel.txt Personnel template

      • content Data frame of personnel template, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

    • taxonomicCoverage.xml Taxonomic coverage EML element

      • content EML::taxonomicCoverage, NA otherwise

      • path Path to file, NA otherwise

  • data.table Data tables

    • data.table.name.ext Name of data table including file extension, NULL otherwise

      • content Data frame of data table

      • path Path to data table (required if data.table exists)

  • other.entity Other entities

    • other.entity.name.ext Name of other entity including file extension, NULL otherwise

      • content Set to NA

      • path Path to other entity (required if data.table exists)

  • argument A list of arguments to be passed to make_eml(). Other EMLassemblyline functions don't yet accept this input.

    • data.path (character) Path to where the data files are stored. This path must be valid when passing the list structure to make_eml() because this is where checksum values are calculated.

    • data.table (character) Data table name(s). If more than one, then supply as a vector of character strings (e.g. data.table = c("concentrations.csv", "characteristics.csv")).

    • data.table.description (character) Data table description(s). Brief description of data.table. If more than one, then supply as a vector of character strings in the same order as listed in data.table.

    • data.table.quote.character (character) Quote character(s) used in data.table. If more than one, then supply as a vector of character strings in the same order as listed in data.table. This argument is required only if your data contain quotations. If the quote character is a quotation, then enter "\"". If the quote character is an apostrophe, then enter "\'".

    • data.url (character) The URL of where your data can be downloaded by a data repository. This argument is not required, if the data will be manually uploaded to a data repository.

    • dataset.title (character) Dataset title. Be descriptive (more than 5 words) and consider including the temporal coverage (e.g. "GLEON: Long term lake chloride concentrations from North America and Europe: 1940-2016").

    • eml.path (character) Path to where the EML will be written.

    • geographic.coordinates (character) Geographic coordinates delineating the bounding area or point of a dataset, in decimal degrees. This argument is not required if using bounding_boxes.txt. Values must be listed in this order: North, East, South, West. Longitudes West of the prime meridian and latitudes South of the equator are negative. If representing a point, repeat the latitude for North and South, and repeat the longitude for East and West (e.g. geographic.coordinates = c('28.38', '-119.95', '28.38', '-119.95')).

    • geographic.description (character) Geographic description. Don't use this argument if geographic coordinates in the bounding_boxes.txt template.

    • maintenance.description (character) Indicator of whether data collection is ongoing or completed.

    • other.entity (character) Name(s) of other.entity(s) in this dataset. Use other.entity for all non-data.table files. other.entity(s) should be stored at data.path.

    • other.entity.description (character) Description(s) of other.entity(s). If more than one, then supply as a vector of descriptions in the same order as listed in other.entity.

    • package.id (character) EDI Data Repository Data package ID for this dataset. A missing package ID defaults to edi.101.1.

    • path (character) Path to where the template(s) will be stored.

    • provenance (character) EDI Data Repository Data package ID(s) corresponding to parent datasets from which this dataset was created (e.g. knb-lter-cap.46.3).

    • return.obj (logical) Return the EML as an R object of class EML object.

    • temporal.coverage (character) Beginning and ending dates of the dataset as a vector of character strings in the format YYYY-MM-DD.

    • user.domain (character) Domain of the user.id(s). Valid options for EDI are LTER and EDI. If more than one, supply as a vector of character strings in the same order as corresponding user.id(s). This argument is not required.

    • user.id (character) ID(s) of data repository user account(s). If more than one, supply as a vector of character strings. Contact EDI (info@environmentaldatainitiative.org) to obtain one. This argument is not required.

    • write.file (logical) Write file to eml.path.

Note

Paths to data tables and other entities must be valid when passing the list structure to make_eml(). Paths to other content is optional.

Contents

  • Arguments
  • Value
  • Note
